intro: Alaternus sempervirens var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf hawthorn, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, lance-shaped leaves that are typically 2–4 inches long and have a smooth, waxy surface. The plant produces clusters of small, white flowers in the spring, followed by red berries in the fall. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil. This variety is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and wildlife habitat benefits.
